content:
This is a terrible challenge and statement because of the special case being SO UNCLEAR:

"Characters other than numbers, P and N should be ignored."

This can mean two very different things.
The obvious thing is that if you ignore them, but they still act as separators between digits:
e.g.

"PPP2+3" -> 6+9 = 15
but what you have is that they should be basically removed before you start:
"PPP2+3" -> "PPP23" -> 69

This needs to be better explained, because it's impossible to figure out via debugging. Not sure why you made such a complication in the clash.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Everything seems ok !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and simple, but still with a twist if one doesn't handle invalid characters between digits correctly.

Very nice problem. There are a couple of typos though:

* "must be multiply" -> "must be multiplied"
* "all multiplication result" -> "all of the multiplication results"
* "Here some examples" -> "Here are some examples"
* "should start by" -> "should start with"

Also, I am not sure the first special case needs to be specified, because it is not really a special case. If the string starts with a number, it shall be multiplied by the multiplier according to the rules. It just happens that the multiplier is always 0 in this case. And if the string ends with a P or N, that just increases the multiplier. The fact that there is no number using that multiplier doesn't contradict the rules either.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Just the right difficulty

Goal section
* You may format "P" and "N" under "Special cases" as {{constants}} too.
* You may remove all the quotation marks.
* Better split each example into one line per step for easier reading, and also because the end of the line is cut off if the window is not wide enough.

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement.

Thanks.

Thank you for the feedback.

It should be ok now.
Also, you should remove the first test case and the first validator as they just duplicate later tests and validators.
I added an explanation in the statement.
Yes you're right, thk you for the typos and advices.
